comments.commentBody: The fact that Ambassador Sergey Kisliak is one of Putin's top sypmaster's is enough to sink most of trump's adminstration. That is, if what Gail is telling us. That is, if the donald's inner 'campaign surrogates' members were as casual about having all these "little chats" with the "Top Recruiter" for Russian intelligence advantages. Whether from Cleveland before, after and beyond (from all directions), any American officials that directly had 'talks', including trump and his entourage and especially with Secret Service protection for the big guy have much to account for. So from Putin's mouth to trump's ears and vice versa the truth will never come out, nor be believed. The taint can never be bottled up.

Those are not "demands of the base." They are the excuses of the status quo, trying to keep power.

The danger is not just of distraction. It is even more of distortion.

Wars have come of political leaders acting out for domestic reasons. We are creating a situation in which Trump is pushed to prove something by acting. Any possible actions will serve the interests of the War Party portion of those pushing him.

Our domestic politics are likely to show their distorting effects on our most serious problems, because those are the ones to come up. North Korea is a dangerous example.

I'm convinced that the least imperfect answer for North Korea involves doing a deal with China. The current events are foreclosing such deals, in fact are meant by too many doing them to foreclose such deals, what they see not as a flaw but as a feature.
There is one group that Scott Walker will never stand strong against: his employers, Charles and David Koch. When they give him an order, he jumps out of his chair to say "Yes sir!"
The Republicans in the trump administration think they are Uber Republicans and are allowed to have their own set of rules.

What, specifically, are the charges here? So far it's a lot of yelling about meetings with the Russian ambassador that both parties had and forgot about.

What, specifically, are democrats alleging took place at those meetings? Details, please. If Obama actually had more detail, it's likely he would have released them when he had the power of the presidency at his disposal. It appears he has nothing more than the fact that these meetings took place, which wiith that ambassador, means little.

The natural terminus of this thinking is the dissolution of the US. I think at this point the "big government" liberals on the West Coast would be happy to secede. After all generosity to the red states has it's limits, perhaps it IS time to keep our Federal tax dollars in state...all of them....for good.
This message brought to you by the Koch brothers.

As a Madisonian, I thank you Larry E.
Wonderfully put!

Sure I could go for more 'power' to state government if you are talking about a state like California which under democratic leadership and policies has done very well. If you want to talk about Republican state leadership, Kentucky's failures come to mind.

" I personally made the case for returning authority to the states — and more important to the people — to President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and congressional Republicans. This is how our founders envisioned our country," -- Scott Walker

Actually that is not "how our founders envisioned our country." As any serious student of American history and the constitutional convention knows, the new constituionn was about taking authority from the states, formerly colonies, who under the Articles of Confederation maintained a degree of soverienty that was disruptive to commerce, and placing it in the hands of a stronger federal government with control over interstate commerce as well as foreign. The original impetus to the convention was only to address issues of commerce among the states and foreign powers; it quickly evolved into a broader scope that resulted in our Constitution and a much stronger federal government than had existed beforehand. That was the issue that was then debated and publicized in the Federalist Papers: whether the federal government should be strengthened not weakened.

No doubt the power and reach of the federal government has gone beyond what "our founders envisioned our country," but to assert that they wanted to "return. . . authority to the states" is an alternative fact. You can look this up. See Madison's DEBATES IN THE FEDERAL CONVENTION OF 1787.

Walker says he takes the "high road" - apparently as in "put-up or shut-up."

Must be why he, like trump, is underwater.
Whoa! That comment has plenty of ALL CAPS, so it can't be your nicer twin who wrote it, it MUST be YOU.  Hmmmm...... the Kool-Aid must've gone flat.
Please, don't expect try to confuse a Republi-cant with "alternative facts"; you might confuse him....
Scott Walker's advice is straight out of Marie Antoinette's playbook. Maybe he should check a history book and see how that worked for her.

And how is that Presidential primary race working for you? Oh, dropped out? Cohn bros. money was wasted? Maybe you should have finished college and learned something. What the good people of WI see in you I have no idea. How you survived a recall baffles me further. How workers would undermine their own bargaining rights under the misnomer "right to work" would baffle a high schooler in any other State. Maybe you have "right to vote" laws in WI I'm unaware of.
The reason angry folks have confronted their representatives to DC has been obvious, and contrary to your assertions, they have all been grass root protests. Thank you Donald Trump, you have united the country, against you and your GOP stooges. What was the GOP platform again? What in what Trump has proposed relates to that?
I haven't taken to the streets since 1972 and the Viet Nam War protests. I'm back, as are many of my similar aged friends.

I am having a difficult time controlling my fury, and blood pressure, after reading this clap-trap.  You, SIR, are the epitome of the self absorbed, hypocritical GOP fraud who decimated an entire state, in a remarkably short time.  Shameless, as in you obviously have NONE.  Continue to preach to your brain dead supporters, as you wish,  but you aren't fooling anyone intelligent enough to read THIS publication.   Please, slink back into your hole. I had almost forgotten about you.  Is that your reasoning for this??  Feeling neglected???  Get used to it.  There's a bigger and more entertaining fraudster in town.   Bigly.
I don't pay for the New York Times to read this claptrap.

Gov Walker wrote:
"While not easy, I decided to take the high road: We learned how to make positive arguments, to communicate constantly and to remind people of our promises. And it worked. Republicans in Congress should heed these lessons."

I'm not going to argue whether it has "worked" in Wisconsin. But here's a question for you:

Why didn't YOU encourage your Republi-cant colleagues in Congress to "take the high road" during their 8 years of obstruction against President Obama? Why didn't YOU speak out and remind them of their oath (i.e. to make the government work FOR the people)? Why didn't YOU ask them why they refused to communicate and work with President Obama in any positive way?

YOU had the past 8 years to encourage the intransigent Republi-cants in Congress to heed your advice: "Let’s face the voters — and get to work." But you sat in silence. Why?

Here's why: Because you're nothing more than a partisan hack. "Don’t let the left shape the debate." Excuse me, but YOUR party doesn't have a monopoly on worthy ideas; the Left has ideas that should indeed "shape the debate" alongside yours. COMPROMISE is not a dirty word!

Your partisan divisiveness is clear behind your verbal legerdemain: In your column, not once did you refer to your opposition party by its proper name: Democrats. Rather, you spit out the L-words "left" and "liberals," as if they are anathemas.

Your party's meme of demonizing us as an enemy deserves our protests. We're just getting started!

They voted, what 50 times to repeal?  They had had almost 8 years tp make t better and they still have nothing.  Now you want to risk the health of millions of Americans by giving them less than a year to fix what  they could not fix in 8 years?   In reality they don't want to fix the ACA.  They want to destroy it and the healthcare it provides for millions of Americans.  SAD!!!!

So Scott. Tooting your own horn, but your facts don't add up. Good thing all the folks in the urban areas support you with their federal taxes! And in your next life try living on a non-union salary or minimum wage without healthcare.

You sure are a little fascist, aren't you, Scotty??? BTW, how is Wisconsin's economy doing under you? I heard you crashed and burned it! Yay!! For Republican policies! Did you notice the most conservative states in the country are also the poorest?! And all of the wealthiest states are the most liberal: Evil California, Naughty New York, Monstrous Massachusetts?? I wonder why that is? I know one thing - conservative states will never figure it out. Sad!

Mr. Walker- I watched a GOP congressman insist to an angry town hall full of his constituents that Obamacare had 'Death Panels."
Are you really encouraging your colleagues to stand firm on nonsense & ignorant scare tactics that wholly mislead ?
The problem is the GOP does NOT have a better health insurance plan or reasonable balance of commitment to public protection:
-EPA,FDA,FEMA,CDC and rational control of pollution/CO2
- sound tax reform, not trickle down fantasyland
- pragmatic immigration legislation (not a $300billion wall)
- serious infrastructure spending
- public education
- reproductive choice
- minimum wage increase

Stand firm on what ???

as to corporate profits ?
Scott Walker (R-Divide and Conquer) gave Wisconsin the political toxicity President* took national.
A regular "Mr. Walker Goes to...Madison."  As one well-known performer of political theater would tweet:  Sad!

"Put-up or shut up". OK.  The GOP has promised a replacement  for the ACA.  Where is it? Also, why would the GOP gov. Of Kentucky want to repeal the ACA when a significant number of people in  Kentucky want their ACA, but not the Obama care?
